q.a: let's skip the harmony and just look at melodies. in most songs, they don't use all the notes. they tend to use some, but kind of skip the ones in between. typically if you lay out all 12 notes in order, xxxxxxxxxxxx, an ordinary song for example usually is only gonna use these notes 0x0x00x0x0x0. you'll notice that's uneven. and if you're wondering what happens when it's completely evenly distributed: 0x0x0x0x0x0x, well you'll notice it sounds like you are spinning around. i've still left most of life's most important questions unanswered, but hopefully this is a more direct way of accessing the conundrum you mentioned, which has nothing to do with harmony

And then the second guitar comes in and harmonizes over the first and I figured out that the harmony is a minor third (correct me if im wrong). But here's the confusion: the notes in the harmony are A D C# E, and A D E are all a minor third of the corresponding notes in guitar 1 - F# B C#. BUT the C# in guitar 2 is a MAJOR THIRD away from the A in guitar 1. And it sounds bloody cool. q.q: hey bill, it's the dom9no3 chord guy whose question you didn't follow when I initially asked it. This is what I was getting at (more fleshed out). The dom9 chord (e.g. G9: G-B-D-F-A) is probably the most consonant

q.a: i'd call it Dmin over G, which is rampantly common, especially in the 1970s 'funk' sort of things. it can be used in the place of G9 or Gmin9. you wouldn't have to specify. james brown songs use these all day. i use them all the time
q.q: combination of 5 notes that we have in the 12-note scale. In lots of compositions, chords are more frequently thought of in 4 voices instead of 5 (thank u bach chorales), so we frequently encounter chords that are 4 out of the 5 notes of a dominant 9 chord. Using the G chord, we have G7 = G9 no9, Gadd9 = G9 no7, Dm6 = B hdim7 = G9 no1, and I sometimes also see G9 approximated in 4 voices by leaving out the 5th. These four are all pretty common chords, all quite consonant. But the 5th 4-pitch chord coming from the dom9 that should be just as consonant as the other 4 is G9 no3 = {D,F,G,A} = d minor add4.

q.a: if you put the bass on G, which i think is where it's supposed to be according to your study, i think you will find it much more commonly. or actually perhaps the lead sheet will just say G9 or Gmin9 but in reality the execution will leave out the 3rd
q.q: The frequency I see minor add4 chords in leadsheets and such is basically zero compared to the other 4 chords that are dom9 chords omitting 1 of the 5 notes.

q.a: this study is not really taking account for where the bass is

OK bill, I need you to please please please help me out on this one:

I have watched your interview with H3H3 I don't know how many times (too many), 'cause say what you want, but I think it's reeeally good. The part that I can't stop going back to over and over is when you talk about schedules, which are absolutely crucial for *getting things done*. Without them I've also noticed that there are just so many options, and you end up being all over the place, and one thing can go on forever.

Now, I'm pretty darn good at planning and making schedules, but where I mess up is in the execution. I can't stick to my plans mainly because I get distracted. As soon as whatever was planned on the schedule starts getting a bit difficult, or uncomfortable, I stop doing it and switch to a non-planned activity such as reading the news on twitter, or some other lame thing like that.

Now don't get me wrong, I really want to do the thing s that I 've planned and are on the schedule, I like those things and I feel enthusiastic about it, it's just that whenever it gets hard, I'm too weak.

What's the secret to stick to the schedule no. matter. what.?

I don't want to get old and be like: "arghasdh... I was meant to do all those good things, but I was way too weak to end them D: ...I hate myself! "

I have some reasons ehy I think it could be:

0:30 "I think I'm dying but I'm just being born"
Pretty self explanatory

0:37 "Through the terminal we all shall go"
We all have to die, it's terminal

The repeated use of "unusual" between 0:48 and 1:01 might be hinting towards death, as death would feel very unusual

1:06 "And I'm saying goodbye to the world I know"
Again, death, leaving the world behind

1:15 "Through the terminal we all can grow"
Rebirth perhaps?

1:20 "And it's time to let go"
Letting go of the world, accepting your death

1:43 "...Imagining where all the planes are going"
Reference to the possible existence of heaven?

1:56 "I'm on the next flight"
Rebirth

2:02 "We'll fly through the night till the day becomes bright"
Being in a mother's womb until being born

2:05 "until the night returns"
Until death again

2:31 "One day soon we'll all be together"
We will all join each other after death

q.a: nothing really, that first line is just one of many other song ideas from a song idea generating session. not even the best one, probably one of the worst actually. but the reason it got picked for recording was due to time constraints. i kept narrowing it down and ended up excluding all the choices for not being good enough until i narrowed it down to 1 but then i excluded that one too for not being good enough. 'bad thing' was excluded way earlier, because it was one of the least good. so after having eventually excluding them all for not being good enough, i realized i was at a dead end and the clock was running out so for a twist i just kind of picked one of the worst ones, and wrote it extremely quickly. this was actually an advantage, because when you try to make a bad thing good in a very short amount of time, you are forced to bring out your very best. it's kind of like when it's 8:59 and the bread store is closing at 9:00, you will discover some automobile maneuvering skills you perhaps didn't know you had, just to get that bread

q.q: I have a weird situation. About four years ago I finally stepped into making and singing music after growing up in an family that believed music making, esp singing, is the realm of an elite few talented people. I always rebelled against this idea in my heart because but didn't participate in misic making until I left that environment about 4 yrs ago. anyways, after 4 years of singing w a vocal group I could just feel that my voice, my ears, improv and other abilities had become quite strong. About 6 mo ago I leveled up again in my understanding of music and began making/recording my own music and performing more on my own time, not just with my group. So, I know my strongest suit is harmony and singing with others, but recently at a mic night I sang a song (used a mic) by myself, no accompanymnent, which is a first for me. Icould hear myself during and it I was delighted that my voice both sounded and felt good, which i have learned are some of several markers that you are making a good, strong sound. But a friend recorded it, then sent it to me later. I watched it to see what it sojnded like from an audiences persective and it actually didn't sound great, not bad but not good. There were a few notes I thought I nailed but were actually a little shaky, and overall tone was not as strong as I had felt it was in the moment. This devastates me because my body and my ears to ears told me it sounded nice while I was performing, but the actual recorded audio denies this...I feel shattered. So now I am wondering if I should just halt all my musical persuits,

q.a: that was a sort of insecurity defense mechanism. i was feeling hopeless, jobless, didn't really know how i was gonna get it together. was envious of people who had serious full time music biz careers, such as (for example) writing custom jingle songs for commercials! this is actually mostly a thing of the past, but i was fantasizing i guess. and i was hungry for burger king, but when you don't have a job you simply just can't just simply go out a spend money on burger king. so some kind of dillusional logic in my mind told me that if i could write and record a 30 second jingle for burger king, on the spot, that would at least justify going there somehow. so i did it. unfortunately the cutoff was not professional in the slightest, the damn thing ran way over, to like 34 maybe? but at least it got finished successfully, during a time when i was mostly way too confused to even exceed 5 seconds! so sure enough i did the 30+ burger king one and promptly went to actual burger king, which for the folks at home would be the one near astoria boulevard next to the N train

q.q: okay, so, this is long but hear me out. i live in super-serious college land with super-serious computer science people and i'm stuck here until summer, and then for the next 2 years (i'm already too deep to quit now). over the last three years or so i have been too afraid of being free. i live in this bubble where i pretend to be someone i'm not, even to the point where i'll just randomly want to burst out singing in public because i know it would cheer everyone up. i'm really a music and fitness guy who didn't have the balls to just try being a freelance musician, so i just relied on college. But now, i've realized college doesn't help me learn anything and also college sucks and i hate it.So basically, i'm a 5-year-old trapped in a young adult's body. i know that once i start being myself and fully commit to it, there will be no turning back to the old way of thinking, and i'm honestly completely okay with that, except i'm naturally a more "out-there" person than most people and many people i know, (including professors) can and have seen my assertiveness and certainty as disrespect or rudeness. I've requested a solo room so i can be a weirdo and make content in there without anyone judging me, so that's at least a start i guess. Point is, i'm going to change eventually, but the question is just time. My gut is telling me to break out of this mentality now, the sooner the better. I guess the question is, in your experience, is it beneficial to your insecurity around other people to start being yourself fully around them,

q.a: don't worry about that. simply listen to the song all up to its current point, and imagine what you want the next part to sound like. then find out what those notes and chords were. then the analysts (maybe you, maybe someone else, ...) can try to figure out what key they went to. sometimes people may even disagree on what key it was, because when you change keys you have opened the door to change, and sometimes you may be roaming the hallways instead of going explicitly into 1 room. or in some cases you may have entered a room but through the side door, which can cause potential disagreements about which key it was. but it still sounds the way it sounds so just pay attention to what sound you want. unless you are making music primarily for a wall decoration, in which case you should use B# major, to wow your guests

q.a: that method seems very strange to me, but it might work, if you are not used to coming up with everything all at the same time. my approach to the over-whelm of not knowing what to do would be to just simply make much much much much much shorter products. and if it still doesn't work try making it shorter. a good example of the first one i did on this strategy was "die", literally only syllable. 1 word, 1 syllable, 1 melody note, 1 chord, 1 bass note, 1 kick drum, etc.... conceived of quite instantly, and recorded very quickly, because it was very clear what to do. that one was supposed to be 1 second, so the next one can be 2 seconds, except i discovered that the ringing crash cymbal made it 2 seconds so i actually went shorter first and did one that was truly 1 second, which was 'bears', before moving onto 2 seconds

q.a: no, what happened is i finally realized once and for all that youtube is now recommending videos much more if they have stronger monetization. i have heard rumors that they would start doing this and knew they would eventually, but i proved it very clearly recently. because the ball and stick video was listed as #2 on trending when you click into the trending list, but, it was not showing up in recommendations where top 5 trending videos are supposed to show up. i did a test on a clean cookie-free (identity-free) browser, and went to youtube.com. on the front page of youtube, the top row of 5 videos is recommended trending videos. if you keep refreshing it, it seems to display mostly videos from the top 8 or so, switching around slightly with each refresh but usually mostly the same videos, all taken from the top of the trending list. but i refreshed it several times and mine was simply never there, despite being listed as #2 on the actual trending list. so i did an experiment and turned on 5 sec skippables for that video, and it instantly started appearing on the front page every time. so essentially this proves to me that the youtube algorhythm is strongly favoring videos with better monetization, which i always suspected would eventually be true. so essentially i can no longer trust youtube to give my videos a fair shake if they have the weakest monetization settings (i.e. display ads only). the good news is, i still offer all my content downloadable for free on billwurtz dot com, so they can be played in an offline video player of your choosing, which for me personally is the way i strongly prefer to watch content anyway. in fact i never even wanted to join youtube because i can't stand watching videos in an online streaming player. much prefer to download. but i gotta get the stuff on as many sites as possible, and play by their rules if necessary. after all that's probably how most of you found me

q.q: Out of curiosity I slowed down Mount St. Helens to listen more closely to the rhythm of the vocals during the parts where it sounds like you're singing too many syllables over one beat (e.g. "and it's gonna be a" on beat 4 of measure 1). What it seems like you are consistently doing is having three accents during the beat ("AND it's GONna BE a"), but when I listened more closely you aren't doing a triplet feel over the beat, but rather, depending on the words in each particular occurrence, a 3-3-2, 3-2-3, or 2-3-3 pattern of 32nd notes (which fits better with the 16th note rhythms in the instruments than a triplet would). My question is: are you intentionally writing the melody with 32nd note syncopation like that?

Or are you just thinking about doing 3 accents over the beat? Either way, I'm impressed. Either you're successfully performing a near-impossible rhythm that you've written, or you're naturally creating one by ear as you try to sing with the best feel you can.
